On approval of the specialisation authority, a 6 UOC project/thesis may be undertaken in the Master program, if the student has achieved a credit average in other completed courses. A project involves an independent investigation at an advanced level by the student and may include research, design, feasibility or other analysis requiring integration of knowledge and evaluation across a range of topics in the area of specialisation. Work based projects are encouraged for practising engineers provided they meet the requirements of advanced independent study. Work based projects must be approved by the program authority prior to commencement of the project.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE0024 - Project 24 Units of Credit","description":"

On approval of the specialisation authority, a 24 UOC project/thesis may be undertaken in the Master Extension program, if the student has achieved a credit average in other completed courses. A project involves an independent investigation at an advanced level by the student and may include research, design, feasibility or other analysis requiring integration of knowledge and evaluation across a range of topics in the area of specialisation. Work based projects are encouraged for practising engineers provided they meet the requirements of advanced independent study. Work based projects must be approved by the program authority prior to commencement of the project.

of Engineering","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9010 - Engineering Postgraduate Coursework Research Skills","description":"

This course is designed to develop research and communication skills and strategies that would support the Research Project component of the program. There are weekly guest lectures and tutorials, Moodle course activities and assignments. The course themes include: formulating a research topic, managing a research project, locating and critically evaluating the literature, engineering research methods,  writing about research, speaking about research, academic integrity.


Students will critically review literature; formulate a research program for a small topic in an area of engineering; develop interpersonal skills needed for project management and collaborative research; and communicate their research topic to expert and non-expert audiences.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6e50d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961910","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collaborative Research Group Workspace","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will form into collaborative research groups of size around 20. Each group will consider a research problem in a particular area of engineering (an Engineering Research Challenge). Together, the group will develop an online resource which explores the area and contains: an overview of the area, with outstanding research challenges; any existing work towards solving the problems; sub-problems which could be tackled and how they might be approached. This will be developed as a group-based Wiki under the Moodle Wiki module.


Each group will be assigned a mark based on the quality of the material on the Wiki. Individuals will be assessed based on their contribution to the Wiki.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e650d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e650d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ee50d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ee50d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961913","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2250d967db69bc50be4672f5f396191b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Engineering Challenge Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Students write a report on an engineering research challenge that they have worked on in their collaborative research groups. The report must include at least: an overview of the problem space (literature review) and a proposal for a small research program to investigate some part of the problem. It should be written in the style of a grant proposal (e.g. ARC Discovery Grant proposal).


The report will be assessed by both the course convenors and by peers within their own collaborative research group. Most of the assessment weight is assigned to the course convenor.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e650d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e650d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ee50d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961913","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3e50d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quiz 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"5","description":"

An online multiple-choice quiz which will run in the tutorial class during week 10, dealing with a selection of topics covered up to that point.


Marks are automatically computed via the Moodle quiz tool.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6650d967db69bc50be4672f5f3961919","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lecture/Workshop Facilitation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Each student will facilitate a workshop during one lecture/workshop session, working with a partner. They will be given material and suggestions for exercises in the one week and need to fully-develop the exercises, and then run the workshop using the exercises during the lecture/workshop session in the following week.


Students will be assessed by the staff in the course, who will consider the material distributed during the session and how effectively the workshop was facilitated. A small component of the assessment will also come from evaluation provided by the students who participated in the session.

contentlets.keywords: engineering,engineering research culture,research training,project management,research genres,critical thinking,written and spoken communication,research methodology
contentlets.description:
This course is designed to develop research and communication skills and strategies that would support the Research Project component of the program. There are weekly guest lectures and tutorials, Moodle course activities and assignments. The course themes include: formulating a research topic, managing a research project, locating and critically evaluating the literature, engineering research methods,  writing about research, speaking about research, academic integrity.

Students will critically review literature; formulate a research program for a small topic in an area of engineering; develop interpersonal skills needed for project management and collaborative research; and communicate their research topic to expert and non-expert audiences.

This course is a distance version of the face-to-face delivery GSOE9010 course and is designed to develop research and communication skills and strategies that would support research aspects of the students' masters program. The course will take a flipped classroom approach with topics covered including


  • Writing skills
  • Statistics
  • Literature search
  • Group dynamics
  • Research profile and grants
  • Experimental design
  • Presenting
  • Publishing, citing, bibliographic tools, plagiarism

Students will contribute to online discussions, lead discussion activities, participate in lecture discussions, take on-line quizzes. Students will also write a written report that will be a literature review including analysis of experimental techniques, plus a proposal for a potential novel project in the topic area. This proposal should be written like a grant application, based on ARC guidelines.

of Engineering","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"GSOE9017 - Managing Energy Efficiency","description":"

If Australia and the world are to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, both renewable energy and more efficient use of that energy will be required. Energy efficiency is the cheapest, fastest, safest and simplest way to reduce emissions. This course covers the various methodologies, technologies and policies that can be used to reduce energy use, while still producing what that energy is needed for - heat, light and movement. Topics covered include current and predicted energy use and associated GHG emissions; residential and commercial passive solar design; energy management programs; building management systems; heating, ventilation and air conditioning; and consumer products and office equipment. The impacts of transport are also covered, together with opportunities to reduce transport energy requirements through more efficient engines, public transport, and urban design. Industrial systems examined include heat recovery; cogeneration; compressed air and steam distribution; and motor systems, pumps and fans. Efficient use of water, and increased efficiency of water supply can also significantly reduce energy use. Various government policy measures at the local, state, commonwealth and international level are covered in terms of their effectiveness and relevance in Australia. Finally, barriers to improved energy efficiency such as up-front cost, lack of information, and the low cost of energy in Australia are examined.Assignments focus on energy use and emissions produced at your home and by your transport to and from the UNSW, and will also analyse current energy practices at the UNSW.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"GSOE9111","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9111 - Energy Storage","description":"

Electrochemical energy storage is the most widely applied clean energy technology in this age and will be the central focus in this course. However, the course will also cover other energy storage technologies with equivalent importance in different fields of application, such as chemical storage, thermal storage, mechanical storage and biomass energy. Students will learn the basic principles of electrochemical technologies in energy storage engineering: rechargeable batteries, flow batteries, supercapacitors, fuel cells, electrolysers, photo-electrochemical reactions, etc.. Students will also be introduced to system integration and energy economy in the context of sustainability.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"93db56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will be able to evaluate their learning efficacy by completing several tests on the core contents related to electrochemical energy principles. Students will receive feedback through tutorial and after-class contact hours.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3db56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dbdb56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dbdb56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5fdb56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Technical analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Following this assessment students will be able to recognize, describe and investigate one or more energy storage systems to assess their feasibility and integration in the context of techno-economic-political-environmental impact. Students are expected to comprehend the engineering principles of the chosen energy storage system and it's integration with an application and/or generation system, and then prepare the presentation using slides or videos. 

\n

Students will be offered the opportunity to communicate/discuss their knowledge and knowhow with a panel of experts in energy storage research. The panel will evaluate the depth and breadth of the students' comprehension of the energy storage technology of their choice. Students will receive immediate feedback on their learning outcomes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3db56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dbdb56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dbdb56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dfdb56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"63db56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb53","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Major project Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"45","description":"

This project aims to prepare students to design and communicate professional solutions to energy storage applications addressing practical energy storage needs. The students are expected to demonstrate good comprehension of the theoretical and technological aspects of energy storage, employ high-level communication skills to offer technological and non-technological (e.g. environmental, political, economic) recommendations, and develop strong capabilities in critical thinking and collaboration through professional teamwork. Student teams will document the process and outcomes of their research in a technical report. Students will also complete team evaluations exercise to provide feedback to their team mates and moderate grades.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d3db56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dbdb56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dbdb56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dfdb56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb2a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"97db56cb1b463c10d5fb0fabdc4bcb4d","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/GSOE9111.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9122 - Integrated Design Studio for High Performance Buildings","description":"

Please Note:  For non-award students, the appropriate background is normally a Bachelor of Engineering.


In Australia and globally, the challenge of climate change is driving growing interest in the design and construction of high performance buildings which are climate appropriate, energy efficient and generate energy from renewable sources. This studio course provides the opportunity for Faculty of Engineering postgraduate students to work together in teams with colleagues from the Faculty of the Built Environment on real world, industry-linked projects focused on the integrated design of sustainable, high performance buildings. The studio will be structured around cross-disciplinary collaboration and integration of low energy, passive design strategies from project conception, and will include opportunities for interaction with experienced industry professionals. Lectures in advanced topics of ESD design and evidence based methods and tools, including evaluation and prediction of building thermal, energy and daylighting performance, will complement and inform students' studio work. 


The course will make use of the Faculty of Engineering's new Design Laboratory.

contentlets.description:
PLEASE NOTE: For non-award students, the appropriate background is normally a Bachelor of Engineering.  Other Bachelor degrees in Science, Commerce and Law might be acceptable. This course will offer flexible delivery, being conducted in blended mode combining 3 face-to-face workshops, online activities and work-place based learning.

Smart grid is the integration of numerous technologies, systems and processes with the aim to modernize and fully automate the entire electricity grid covering generation transmission, distribution, utilization plus conservation. Smart grid will revolutionize the design, development, management, operation and maintenance of the grid to the levels that was thought impossible some decades ago. The drivers towards smart grids include environmental awareness of people and governments; the need for further automation and energy efficiency; large capital investments for the renewal of the ageing infrastructure; adoption of competitive energy prices; security of supply; energy conservation and the ever increasing electricity demand that needs to be met.  The course will provide advanced information and thinking required by engineers and professionals to deliver the smart grid concepts from inception to implementation. The course will mainly focus on intelligent electricity distribution networks, present the latest technologies and analyse the impact of these technologies on system design, operation, management and maintenance.
contentlets.title: Smart Grids and Distribution Networks

A course for graduate electrical, photovoltaic, mechanical and civil engineers covering the basics of design for optimum illuminance and techniques for improved energy efficiency, including choice of light sources, luminaire design, design for maximum use of natural light, the assessment of intrinsic losses of equipment; reducing losses through equipment design selection of materials and management of losses of high harmonic content by non-linear power electronic loads.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9220 - Launching a Startup","description":"

This course aims to provide students with the skills necessary to successfully commercialise ideas. Whilst some aspects of entrepreneurship can be learned from others, research on entrepreneurship education has shown a learn-by-doing approach is most effective. Thus, the course has a strong experiential-learning focus and will incorporate a flipped-classroom model with weekly online topics based on the Lean LaunchPad, which is used by leaders in this space such as Stanford, Berkley and the University of Pennsylvania.


During their project, students form small teams, identify potential business opportunities and utilise enquiry based learning to assess the viability of their business model. Upon completion of their project, students pitch their business model and report on their learnings.

contentlets.description:
This course aims to provide students with the skills necessary to successfully commercialise ideas. Whilst some aspects of entrepreneurship can be learned from others, research on entrepreneurship education has shown a learn-by-doing approach is most effective. Thus, the course has a strong experiential-learning focus and will incorporate a flipped-classroom model with weekly online topics based on the Lean LaunchPad, which is used by leaders in this space such as Stanford, Berkley and the University of Pennsylvania.

During their project, students form small teams, identify potential business opportunities and utilise enquiry based learning to assess the viability of their business model. Upon completion of their project, students pitch their business model and report on their learnings.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"GSOE9340","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9340 - Life Cycle Engineering","description":"

This course is designed to provide postgraduate students with high level knowledge of Life Cycle Engineering principles and practices. The course will follow a typical product life cycle and the associated tools and techniques available. It starts with defining the concept of life cycle engineering, history and potential benefits (ecological and environmental). It then introduces the drivers behind this concept such as legislation and standards, environmental requirements. Next, the concepts of life cycle thinking, Cradle-to-Grave, Cradle-to-Cradle, Energy and Eco-efficiency are introduced. In the following section, generic environmental impact assessment tools and the concept of sustainable product development and the associated eco-design tools are introduced.  The course continues with concepts related to usage and the end-of-life stages of product life cycle. These topics include Product collection, Reverse logistics and End-of-Life decision making, Tools and technologies, Disassemble sequence planning, Disassembly technologies, Reuse and remanufacturing principles, product monitoring and testing, materials recycling techniques. The course finally finishes with economics and future trends such as Economic models, Life Cycle Costing (LCC) and Product Service Systems (PSS).

contentlets.description: This course is designed to provide postgraduate students with high level knowledge of Life Cycle Engineering principles and practices. The course will follow a typical product life cycle and the associated tools and techniques available. It starts with defining the concept of life cycle engineering, history and potential benefits (ecological and environmental). It then introduces the drivers behind this concept such as legislation and standards, environmental requirements. Next, the concepts of life cycle thinking, Cradle-to-Grave, Cradle-to-Cradle, Energy and Eco-efficiency are introduced. In the following section, generic environmental impact assessment tools and the concept of sustainable product development and the associated eco-design tools are introduced.  The course continues with concepts related to usage and the end-of-life stages of product life cycle. These topics include Product collection, Reverse logistics and End-of-Life decision making, Tools and technologies, Disassemble sequence planning, Disassembly technologies, Reuse and remanufacturing principles, product monitoring and testing, materials recycling techniques. The course finally finishes with economics and future trends such as Economic models, Life Cycle Costing (LCC) and Product Service Systems (PSS).
contentlets.title: Life Cycle Engineering

This course is designed to  develop research and communication skills and strategies that would support your research program, and in particular, to prepare you for progression from year 1 to year 2 of your research program. There are weekly guest lectures and tutorials,  Moodle course activities and assignments. The course themes include: Formulating a research topic, managing a research project, locating and critically evaluating the literature, engineering research methods,  writing about research, speaking about research, academic integrity. The course concludes with a  mini-conference on  students proposed research topics.




The course objectives are to develop:

- an increased awareness about the ways successful academic writers structure their writing, and the register of language appropriate for thesis and research writing

- systematic approach in managing research reading and research writing

- increased confidence and improved skills in speaking about research to a range of audiences

- awareness of strengths and weaknesses in communicating and appropriate strategies for improvement.

This course is designed to  develop research and communication skills and strategies that would support your research program, and in particular, to prepare you for progression from year 1 to year 2 of your research program. There are weekly guest lectures and tutorials,  Moodle course activities and assignments. The course themes include: Formulating a research topic, managing a research project, locating and critically evaluating the literature, engineering research methods,  writing about research, speaking about research, academic integrity. The course concludes with a  mini-conference on  students proposed research topics.




The course objectives are to develop:

- an increased awareness about the ways successful academic writers structure their writing, and the register of language appropriate for thesis and research writing

- systematic approach in managing research reading and research writing

- increased confidence and improved skills in speaking about research to a range of audiences

- awareness of strengths and weaknesses in communicating and appropriate strategies for improvement.

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"2 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9410 - Professional Development for Emerging Engineering Educators","description":"

Are you an emerging engineering educator? Do you see yourself as a next-generation academic or teacher? If so, this is the course for you! GSOE9410 provides excellent professional and personal development for you as that emerging educator. Through a series of highly immersive and authentic experiences you will continue to develop and enhance your teaching, extending from your early training in the Faculty. You will participate in highly active and interactive instructional sessions, then identify opportunities to put that instruction into practice, in the context of your own teaching and interests, with the support of the facilitators and other academic staff. You’ll also participate actively with and also support your peers, as they will support you, as well as the broader teaching and learning community, creating a strong ecosystem of practice. At the end of the course, you will see yourself as a better teacher – an emergent engineering educator.

The portfolio is the overarching or 'umbrella' assessment task that evidences all of the subsidiary learning and assessment tasks listed below, with an emphasis upon reflective practice (CLO1, CLO8). This task represents collectively all of the assessment in the course, which is assessed on a SY/FL basis. Thus, the portfolio has been weighted at 100%, and evidences satisfactory completion of all LOs, with various LOs aligned with subsidiary learning and assessment tasks.

\n

The subsidiary tasks include:
*articulation of a teaching philosophy (CLO2)
*• peer observation report/s and rejoinders (360 closed loop, if opportunities allow) (CLO6)
*• reports (and reflections) on professional development activities (CLO7, CLO9)
*• a learning theory investigation (CLO3, CLO9)
* • redesign of an element of a course with which the student is involved, or supported by access to a course through an academic (CLO4, CLO5))

At the end of the course, you will see yourself as a better teacher – an emergent engineering educator.

Engineering","description":"

The role of engineering in society; assessment of technological innovations. Engineering ethics principles and practice; an introduction to ethical systems; the application of ethical frameworks to engineering practice and related technologies; codes of ethics in the professions. Social, legal, environmental and economic considerations; sustainability. Theories of leadership; leadership of teams. Organisation behaviour.

contentlets.description: The role of engineering in society; assessment of technological innovations. Engineering ethics principles and practice; an introduction to ethical systems; the application of ethical frameworks to engineering practice and related technologies; codes of ethics in the professions. Social, legal, environmental and economic considerations; sustainability. Theories of leadership; leadership of teams. Organisation behaviour.
contentlets.title: Ethics and Leadership in Engineering

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9712 - Engineering Statistics and Experiment Design","description":"

This course covers fundamental statistics, design of experiment (DOE), and development of process improvement strategy. Teaching will focus on using engineering industry-based problems, supplemented with the use statistics software package - Minitab. Students will also learn how to compile report to effectively present information from a managerial perspective.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961917","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

The final exam will be centrally managed and will cover all contents in the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"076559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961942","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design of Experiment and Process Improvement Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will work in a team (min. 2, max. 3 members per team) to analyse an industry-based case study. Students have to identify issues, plan experiments to collect data, analyse simulated data, uncover trends and derive improvement strategies for management of the business. Student team will receive feedback via a marking rubrics and personalised feedback upon release of the final result.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"726559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Students have to conduct 3 online quizzes during demonstration session in the computer lab. Each quiz will worth 5% of their final assessment mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cb6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396193d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Data Mining Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will work in a team (min. 2, max. 3 members per team) to uncover information from a dataset. The dataset will contain performance data (simulated) based on an industry process. The dataset will be different for each team. Student team will receive feedback via a marking rubrics and personalised feedback within the 2 weeks after submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f66559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/GSOE9712.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Teaching will focus on using engineering industry-based problems, supplemented with the use statistics software package - Minitab. Students will also learn how to compile report to effectively present information from a managerial perspective.

This course covers fundamental statistics, design of experiment (DOE), and development of process improvement strategy. Teaching will focus on using engineering industry-based problems, supplemented with the use statistics software package - Minitab. Students will also learn how to compile report to effectively present information from a managerial perspective.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961917","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

The final exam will be centrally managed and will cover all contents in the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"076559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961942","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design of Experiment and Process Improvement Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will work in a team (min. 2, max. 3 members per team) to analyse an industry-based case study. Students have to identify issues, plan experiments to collect data, analyse simulated data, uncover trends and derive improvement strategies for management of the business. Student team will receive feedback via a marking rubrics and personalised feedback upon release of the final result.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"726559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Students have to conduct 3 online quizzes during demonstration session in the computer lab. Each quiz will worth 5% of their final assessment mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"766559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f3961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cb6559e3dbe9bc50be4672f5f396193d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Data Mining Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will work in a team (min. 2, max. 3 members per team) to uncover information from a dataset. The dataset will contain performance data (simulated) based on an industry process. The dataset will be different for each team. Student team will receive feedback via a marking rubrics and personalised feedback within the 2 weeks after submission.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9740 - Industrial Ecology and Sustainable Engineering","description":"

Sustainability means living well within the limits of a finite planet. More than ever, engineers need to find holistic and effective solutions to currently unsustainable practices of production and consumption, to protect our vital life support systems and meet the social and economic needs of a growing human population at the same time.


This course teaches concepts and methods to analyse and assess the environmental impacts of industrial systems and economies. It aims to equip students with the ability to understand challenges of sustainability from a local to global scale, to think critically, holistically and with a life cycle perspective and to apply sustainability assessment methods and tools (such as input-output analysis, hybrid life cycle assessment and environmental footprint assessment) in real-world examples.

contentlets.keywords: engineering,environmental sustainability,ecologically sustainable development,industrial ecology,life cycle assessment (lca),environmental footprint,input-output analysis,carbon footprint,water footprint,sustainable engineering,life cycle engineering,integrated sustainability analysis,life cycle costing
contentlets.description:
Sustainability means living well within the limits of a finite planet. More than ever, engineers need to find holistic and effective solutions to currently unsustainable practices of production and consumption, to protect our vital life support systems and meet the social and economic needs of a growing human population at the same time.

This course teaches concepts and methods to analyse and assess the environmental impacts of industrial systems and economies. It aims to equip students with the ability to understand challenges of sustainability from a local to global scale, to think critically, holistically and with a life cycle perspective and to apply sustainability assessment methods and tools (such as input-output analysis, hybrid life cycle assessment and environmental footprint assessment) in real-world examples.
contentlets.title: Industrial Ecology and Sustainable Engineering

contentlets.keywords: engineering,environmental sustainability,ecologically sustainable development,industrial ecology,life cycle assessment (lca),environmental footprint,input-output analysis,carbon footprint,water footprint,sustainable engineering,life cycle engineering,integrated sustainability analysis,life cycle costing
contentlets.description:
Sustainability means living well within the limits of a finite planet. More than ever, engineers need to find holistic and effective solutions to currently unsustainable practices of production and consumption, to protect our vital life support systems and meet the social and economic needs of a growing human population at the same time.

This course teaches concepts and methods to analyse and assess the environmental impacts of industrial systems and economies. It aims to equip students with the ability to understand challenges of sustainability from a local to global scale, to think critically, holistically and with a life cycle perspective and to apply sustainability assessment methods and tools (such as input-output analysis, hybrid life cycle assessment and environmental footprint assessment) in real-world examples.
contentlets.title: Industrial Ecology and Sustainable Engineering

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9758 - Network Systems Architecture","description":"

Pre-requisites: Background in data networks, e.g. TELE3118, COMP3331/9331


This course aims to provide understanding of the design of enterprise and telecommunications network architecture. It will bring together in-depth coverage of various networking technologies (such as TCP/IP, security, wireless LAN 802.11 etc) in order to provide practical context and integration requirements for real-world applications. It covers the methodology behind the design of building enterprise and core networks to support applications that include data, voice and video. Telecommunications architecture will cover IP Multimedia Systems (IMS) and IP Next Generation Networks (IP NGN). Enterprise architecture will review segments within corporate networks referred to as "Places in the Network" (PINs) such as Data Centres, Wide Area Networking (WANs) and remote branches. Other practical applications will include a review of the Australian National Broadband Network (NBN), Cloud Computing and mobile computing.

Telecommunications architecture will cover IP Multimedia Systems (IMS) and IP Next Generation Networks (IP NGN). Enterprise architecture will review segments within corporate networks referred to as "Places in the Network" (PINs) such as Data Centres, Wide Area Networking (WANs) and remote branches. Other practical applications will include a review of the Australian National Broadband Network (NBN), Cloud Computing and mobile computing.
contentlets.title: Network Systems Architecture

Quality control systems, quality systems documentation, manuals, implementation and procedures, quality assurance, quality management systems, lean manufacturing, value-stream mapping, process flows, value added management, voice of the customer, team management, continuous improvement, six-sigma approach, economics of reducing variation in industry, applications.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bfa611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619a9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

Online quiz covers critical material from week 1-3 early in the course

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"33a611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"33a611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3ba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3ba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3ba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619b3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Statistical Process Control Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students are required to analyse a large dataset containing process performance and quality data and to apply appropriate statistical methods to identify the nature and extent of the problems and to use this analysis to suggest improvements to the process.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"33a611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"33a611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3ba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3ba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3fa611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619be","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quality Strategy Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

A quality management case study forms the basis for identifying and understanding engineering quality issues and problems and students are to critically analyse these issues against various drivers (customer requirements, competitors, regulations, organisational skills and capabilities etc) and to generate appropriate and innovative solutions (hypotheses) to these issues.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"33a611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"33a611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3ba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3ba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b3a611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

The final exam covers all material taught in the course

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"33a611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"33a611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3ba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3ba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bba611ebdbe9bc50be4672f5f39619ad","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/GSOE9810.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course will introduce to you the fundamental principles of project management in an engineering context, enabling you to become a successful project manager.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6e271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f396190e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The first in-class activity in each instructional unit is an individual readiness assurance test (iRAT) over the material contained in the preclass assignments.  The combined grade of these iRAT constitute the individual coursework grade. Feedback is provided in the class immediately after test completion.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e6271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e6271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ee271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f396190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ee271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961910","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6e271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f396194b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

When students have finished the iRAT (see Individual Assignment), they turn in their answers and immediately proceed to this assessment item, the team Readiness Assurance Test (tRAT). Students retake the same test, but this time as a team, and the teams must reach agreement on the answers to each test question. 

Feedback is provided instantaneously.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e6271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e6271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ee271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f396190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"72271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961957","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Group assignments provide the students opportunity to deepen their understanding by having groups use the previously introduced concepts to solve a significant problem. These Application Assignments foster both accountability and give-and-take discussion first within and then between groups.  The assignments are carried out predominantly in class, and feedback is provided immediately afterwards.

Marks for group work are moderated by the intra group peer review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e6271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e6271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ee271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f396190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ee271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961910","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e2271d6fdbe9bc50be4672f5f3961914","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The examination evaluates knowledge of the complete course.

Feedback is provided upon release of results.

of Engineering","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"GSOE9841 - Systems Engineering Fundamentals","description":"

Complex systems and systems of systems are numerous and include space systems, health systems, structural systems and transportation systems. The engineering of these complex systems must ensure that many complex parts are properly engineered to work together in order to meet the design requirements. Systems engineering is the collection of principles, processes, guidelines, practices, and frameworks that guide the design and engineering of complex systems in order to ensure they are successfully delivered. This course will introduce students to the discipline of Systems Engineering and is relevant to all areas of engineering. It will cover, amongst others, topics such as Requirements Development and Analysis, Functional Analysis, System Architecting, System Design, System Integration and System Validation. It will also look at trade studies and risk analysis. It will also provide concrete examples from various disciplines.

contentlets.keywords: system engineering,complex systems,system of systems,space systems engineering
contentlets.description: Complex systems and systems of systems are numerous and include space systems, health systems, structural systems and transportation systems. The engineering of these complex systems must ensure that many complex parts are properly engineered to work together in order to meet the design requirements. Systems engineering is the collection of principles, processes, guidelines, practices, and frameworks that guide the design and engineering of complex systems in order to ensure they are successfully delivered. This course will introduce students to the discipline of Systems Engineering and is relevant to all areas of engineering. It will cover, amongst others, topics such as Requirements Development and Analysis, Functional Analysis, System Architecting, System Design, System Integration and System Validation. It will also look at trade studies and risk analysis. It will also provide concrete examples from various disciplines.
contentlets.title: Systems Engineering Fundamentals

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GSOE9997 - Engineering Work Related Learning for Postgraduates","description":"

This course provides students enrolled in degrees without Industrial Training with an opportunity to engage in Work Integrated Learning (WIL). Students will engage in authentic, purposeful, partnered, supervised and assessed work learning experiences that integrate academic learning with its application in the workplace as part of their program of study. It provides the means to ‘do in context’ rather than developing practical skills alone; it enables students to develop work readiness skills to workplace standards and enhances employability. Academic study is paired with between 15 - 50 work days in a self-sourced placement.

Students will explore various skills and processes associated with development and execution of a scientific and/or engineering type project. In doing so, they will build on authentic work integrated learning experiences, and develop relevant career skills for securing future placements. These skills and processes include project management of engineering projects, understanding requirements of clients, effective communication, and interaction with a wide range of stakeholders, other disciplines, professions, and people and presenting yourself both orally and in a written form. It also includes extension into ethical behaviour and organisational theory with an overall aim to develop students’ employability


  • Enrolment in the course is restricted to students who are:
  • Enrolled in a Faculty of Engineering single or dual degree that does not require Industrial Training (co-op students are also ineligible)
  • Have completed a minimum amount of UOC
    • Completion of 30 UoC in program (8338 or 8335 or 8037 or 8059)
    • Completion of 48 UoC in program 8543

  • Have a confirmed WIL placement

Students to submit a placement plan (in discussion with supervisor) at the start of the placement and supervisor to complete employer feedback at the end of the placement. Formative assessment.

Industry interview by expert/s. This task is to close the learning and development loop of this course where students can reflect the entire learning experience from the course and work integrated learning placement through mock interview/s to prepare students to become industry ready.
